journal-title-group.journal-title: Journal of Computational and Graphical Statistics

publisher.publisher-name: American Statistical Association, Institute of Mathematical Statistics, and Interface Foundation of North America

title-group.article-title: Two-Sample T<sub>3</sub> Plot: A Graphical Comparison of Two Distributions

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 2000 American Statistical Association, Institute of Mathematical Statistics, and Interface Foundation of North America

abstract.p: Consider two independent random variables x and y with means and standard deviations μ <sub>x</sub>,μ <sub>y</sub>,σ <sub>x</sub>, and σ <sub>y</sub>, respectively. Let F<sub>x</sub>(t)=P[(x-μ <sub>x</sub>)/σ <sub>x</sub>≤ t] and F<sub>y</sub>(t)=P[(y-μ <sub>y</sub>)/σ <sub>y</sub>≤ t]. In this article we address the problem of testing the null hypothesis <tex-math>$H_{0}\colon F_{x}\equiv F_{y}$</tex-math>, against the alternative <tex-math>$H_{1}\colon F_{x}\not\equiv F_{y}$</tex-math>. A graphical tool called T<sub>3</sub> plot for checking normality of independently and identically distributed univariate data was proposed in an earlier article by Ghosh. In the present article we develop a two-sample T<sub>3</sub> plot where the basic statistic is the normalized difference between the T<sub>3</sub> functions for the two samples. Significant departure of this difference function from the horizontal zero line is indicative of evidence against the null hypothesis. In contrast to the one-sample problem, the common distribution function under the null hypothesis is not specified in the two-sample case. Bootstrap is used to construct the acceptance region under H<sub>0</sub>, for the two-sample T<sub>3</sub> plot.
